title: Financial Modelling in Decision-Making & Business Planning
headline: This free online course will study the role of financial modelling in guiding business decision-making and planning.
description: This free online course on the study of financial modelling in decision-making and business planning provides critical and valuable information on financial business modelling. From there, we explore the basic types of financial modelling. In addition, we explain the steps using a business model example using MS Excel. Finally, we consider the customer acquisition model and how to apply the product and labour cost model.
courseDescription:
This free online course studies the role of financial modelling in decision-making and business planning. You will clearly understand the use of modelling for business planning. We define financial modelling, helping you know how to create your own model correctly. Explore the business process and the starting point. You will learn the key features and the benefits of using financial modelling. The course will also cover a business example, providing you with specific information about how to create a financial model. Furthermore, you will analyse the uses of MS Excel to create various models like the customer acquisition model.

Furthermore, we teach you to identify the revenue and cost models. Examine the correct management of using product and labour cost models. Next, we demonstrate how to properly model the capital investments incorporated in the financial model. What is a capital investment model? How can I use a business plan, financial statements or models to find investors? We will demonstrate the benefits of using the model to receive financial investments. You will analyse the cost of sale in the financial model and learn how to properly create a labour cost and balance sheet model. Lastly, the course will explain how to correct errors in the financial model you created.

This course will give you a better understanding of financial modelling in guiding decision-making and business planning. In addition, you will receive clear and precise methods as a means to apply them in your working field. This course is excellent for those in the financial sector or anyone working in investment banking, equity research, corporate development, financial planning and analysis (FP&A) and accounting.

Start Course Now

  • Lesson Summary

  • This presents a summary of the key content covered.
    • Financial Modelling: Financial modelling is the task of building an abstract representation of a real-world financial situation.
    • Financial modelling is understood to mean an exercise in either asset pricing or corporate finance, of a quantitative nature. It is about translating a set of hypotheses about the behavior of markets or agents into numerical predictions.
    • the key features of the financial model are: to think about the business, research the business, write down all the aspects worth analyzing, and make some educated assumptions.
    • the first step in modelling anything is thinking about everything that is involved in the business and making a list.
    • A financial model has many uses for company executives. Financial analysts most often use it to analyze and anticipate how a company might be affected by future events or executive decisions.
    • The output of a financial model is used for decision-making and performing financial analysis, whether inside or outside of the company. 
    • Inside a company, executives will use financial models to make decisions about: Raising capital, Making acquisitions, Growing the business, organically, Selling or divesting assets and business units, Budgeting and forecasting, Capital allocation, Valuing a business, Financial statement analysis/ratio analysis, Management accounting

  • Case Study - Basic Model - Learning Outcomes

    • Recognize the customer acquisition model with the business model example.
    • Define the revenue and cost models.
    • Evaluate the Product and labor cost model.
    • Define the capital investment model.

  • Case Study - Basic Model - Lesson Summary

  • This presents a summary of the key content covered.
    • Cash projections, and financial projections are some of the decisions you need to make when you start a business.
    • Operation and marketing budgets, Fixed vs Variable cost commitments are included in the "operational decisions" in the financial modelling.
    • The price of the product and the number of customers are used to calculate the revenue in the business.
    • Total addressable market means your maximum potential for growth.
    • The key features of the financial model are: to think about the business, research the business, write down all the aspects worth analyzing, and make some educated assumptions.
    • A financial model has many uses for company executives. Financial analysts most often use it to analyze and anticipate how a company might be affected by future events or executive decisions.
    • The best way to learn financial modelling is to practice. It takes years of experience to become an expert at building a financial model and you really have to learn by doing.
    • It’s also important to establish a solid base understanding by taking professional financial modelling training courses such as ours offered at CFI, with many locations across North America or directly online.

    • Define the labour cost model and the operating expenses model.
    • Evaluate the key features of an income statement model and balance sheet model.

  • Lesson Summary

  • This presents a summary of the key content covered.
    • Advantage or Disadvantage factors are part of the price business model.
    • The value proposition is the extra offered to a customer by your own business.
    • The model cost of operations includes Cost of Sales, Cost of services (Marketing, Administration, Misc), and Cost of labor.
    • Writing down your strategies in the business model will help you gain trust with your investors. Detailed customer acquisition model and revenue model will help you explain your business model to investors.
    • After five years is not recommended to increase the cost of sale in your business model.
    • The expenses on your financial model include the cost of sales, labor cost, and operating cost.
    • The Income statements from the financial model include: Revenue, Cost of sales, and Labor cost.
    • Every financial model starts with a company’s historical results. You begin building the financial model by pulling three years of financial statements and inputting them into Excel.
    • With the forecast assumptions in place, you can calculate the top of the income statement with revenue, COGS, gross profit, and operating expenses down to EBITDA. 
    • With the top of the income statement in place, you can start to fill in the balance sheet. Begin by calculating accounts receivable and inventory, which are both functions of revenue and COGS, as well as the AR days and inventory days assumptions.
